text: 19.30 Part 2 requires major development proposals to submit a Healthy Streets Assessment as part of the transport assessment. By utilising the Healthy Streets Design Check tool which scores proposed street design interventions against the 10 Healthy Street Indicators, the results can be used to measure how design features may improve a potential street, as well as identify areas of poor street design opportunities to make further improvements. [34] 19.31 Part 3 sets out how development proposals should engage positively with the design of high-quality public realm within and in the vicinity of the development, to encourage and enable active travel. Walking and cycling networks must be: z safe; z accessible; z legible and easy to use; z connected; and z convenient. 34 Healthy Streets Design Check England, DfT (2021) BACK TO POLICIES
